comments.commentBody: I'm going to see The Dark World for one reason alone--Tom Hiddleston. I think I'm probably not the only person seeing Thor just to see Loki.
How do you know they're sitting idle?   They may very well be doing business and making money off the books.

In some underdeveloped countries, the informal economy is sizable and pays no taxes, hence, contributes little to none to the obligations  a functioning society incurs. In the U.S., the fact that we have so many out of work, mimics that informality...but worse, as people are sitting idle and nonproductive. So much talent withering away, perhaps on a one way ticket to oblivion. Have we lost our wits, our will to change this sad state of affairs? Is political courage a thing of the past?

Wait. Mitt Romney? He was a presidential candidate, for crying out loud. Or did the SLC Olympics somehow have a mortgage securitization angle that I missed?

Outlandish conspiracy theories are fine, and give some people something to do. But at least keep it only mildly untethered from reality.

So you have figured it out.

Government is supposed to be run for by bankers for the benefit of bankers.

One of the few things Calvin Coolidge said, "The business of America is business."

What he meant to say is, "The business of America is banking, and we're not very good at it."

Will he have any involvement in breaking up banks too big to fail like Bank of America? Capitalism is broken, needs fixing or must be further regulated to protect the market from oligopolies. This is related to inequality of income. If we desire to fix inequality, we must fix capitalism.

"The central problem, then as now, was that very large corporations could easily undermine regulatory and antitrust strategies. The Nobel laureate George J. Stigler demonstrated how regulation was commonly “designed and operated primarily for” the benefit of the industries involved. And numerous conservatives, including Simons, concluded that large corporate players could thwart antitrust “break-them-up” efforts — a view Friedman came to share.
http://bit.ly/FF1207tbr2

Evidently he's thinking that banks are so well run and so dominant in the financial agencies, that we need to spread their influence throughout the rest of the government, beginning with installing Chuck Hagel at DOD and going from there.

All power to the zombie bankers!

Why? If everyone has any dealings with the banking industry is deemed a bad person, it includes a lot of conscientious individuals

Why do people have such a black & white bipolar mindset. Is that Plato was human and therefore everything called 'Plato' is human logic?
Amen Bosco, nice to see a voice of reason.

This will be one more reason why Mr. Obama's supporters are loosing faith in him!
What is he thinking?
TWTR not NFLX?

Before I believe they can grow their earnings enough to justify the price, someone is going to have to explain to me how they generated any sales, not to mention $600 million in them.

Seriously, do people pay to use Twitter? Does anyone actually think they'll ever be able to?

I agree with you for the most part, with one quibble.  Economies shift with what Stephen Jay Gould would call punctuated equilibrium:  long periods of stasis or slight drift, then a catastrophe that shifts the landscape completely.  He meant it in the context of evolutionary biology, but similar logic would apply to the French in 1779, the Americans in 1776, the Russians in 1917, etc. etc.  It didn't work out tidily for the malefactors of wealth and privilege, but it did work - in the context of history - fast.

To keep the elite happy?

No, it was done to keep Obama from having success as our first African American President.

It was done to bankrupt the country by 'starving the beast' in order to divert more money to them, their relatives, and their pay-to-play friends.    We won't be paying off the deficit, the fundamental plan is to pay off the the guys who talk about paying off the deficit.     The fact that it has worked does not bode well for the country.

"It’s really a terrible story: a tale of self-inflicted harm, made all the worse because it was done in the name of responsibility. And the damage continues as we speak. "

It was done in the name of keeping the elite happy. Let's face it. High-level people on Wall Street, in the investment banks, and the corridors of power in DC, are the last to see the consequences of pursuing austerity policies. They keep their high-salaries, their kids get to stay in expensive private schools, regardless of their actions.

So why would they pursue a policy of full employment, when they and their friends are already employed?

What is derp is torching your present and near future with the aim of assuring a prosperous long-term. What is even derpier is encouraging the flight of investment and manufacturing, and the retention of high unemployment, and expecting an the recovery of economy that depends on its consumers. What is criminally derp is choking the very government that provides services and a safety net to the point where it, itself, contributes to the overall unemployment in the millions, nationwide.

When consumers have no jobs and no money, they don't consume. When consumers don't buy, the factory orders go down. When the factory orders go down, businesses fail. When the safety net is cut, less people can access basic goods, such as food. Those same people stop buying the things farmers and grocers sell. Grocers fail. Farmers fail.

Putting people back to work, pumping money into the economy and the treasury makes perfect sense. Repeating the same zombie austerity tropes all the way from Japan, does not.

Most of those "fat cats" are actually institutional investors, many of which are managing average citizens' pensions/retirement accounts. Thus ordinary folk are getting in on it too.

We would avoid these problems if we used an auction, though.

Companies sell stock to make money for themselves that they can then use to invest and grow. Facebook got it right. Twitter got suckered as most companies do. The connected fat cats (never ordinary Joe Citizen) offered the rights to buy the stock at a discount instantly made almost as much as the company got for itself. A good deal for them, and the banks that let them as a quid pro quo for their business, but not the company. Twitter was scammed.

No crime but a built-in unfairness factor, yes, assuming you got in at $26 or less when the majority of investors were prevented from participating because of the way these IPOs are structured to benefit the wealthy.  That said, I also recognize that the price could have gone south of $26 in 20 minutes or less.  You simply lucked out. And good for you.

Twitter still needs to deliver on its business model. Twitter’s loss widened to $64.6 million in the September quarter from $21.6 million a year earlier, and it is unlikely to be profitable until 2015, according to the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. LinkedIn and Facebook were both profitable at the time of their IPOs.

While Twitter’s revenue has surged, reaching $534.5 million in the 12 months that ended Sept. 30, user growth is slowing, filings show. Twitter had 231.7 million monthly users in the quarter that ended in September, up 39% from a year earlier. That compares with 65% growth in the prior year.

Twitter should be a protocol, not a company.
More tech insanity and "investors" without a clue.

But who cares, the bankers and the lawyers will get their payday no matter what happens.

The "early shareholders" to whom you refer ARE Insiders.

IPOs are the most obvious example of insider trading that there is.

After half remembering, half guessing that *F*RIA was the most likely Agua ___ River, I still can't figure out ASDF...Oh okay, I get it.

Never heard the term 'home row' before.
I'm with Rich. What a wonderful sentence. I suspect I'll be using it myself in the future. In fact just hearing 'Tanganyika' again takes me back to a classroom in 1964...

Wonderful story sbm, and humorously related, and we really appreciate your having "slipped' it to us!

Howie flees into his MC...aFreud for his life!

pecanT, The classroom you're alluding to back in 64, was of course, 5th grade, but naturally! :-)

Howie

Nostalgic moment for me. When I was a freshman in high school, I made the varsity baseball team, but was a scrub. One of my jobs was to act as relay man when the coach ht flyballs to the outfielders. The coach popped one up midway between me and the catcher. He yelled for the catcher to take it, but I didn't hear the call and the catcher and i collided, knocking me unconscious. I awoke on the bench some time later and knew I was OK because the capital of Tanganyika popped into my head. I should have kept it to myself, but instead announced why I was OK. Needless to say, I never lived it down, Over the years, the list of questions (atomic weight of carbon, Charlemagne's father) I supposedly asked myself expanded, but DAR ES SALAAM was the only one. Finding out what it means today makes me wonder if it was Freudian.

I thought the puzzle was fun and actually thought the clue for ASDF was pretty clever.

Facebook's IPO was extremely successful: they left no money on the table.  Twitter allowed itself to be plucked: it left nearly half it's money on the table.  Management team apparently clueless. Future therefore dim. Time to short.

I, myself am very excited to here the news, very pessimistic comment by Michael Curves is a great place for the busy woman who has not the time nor energy to figure out her workout, Curves does it for you, which it seems Jenny Craig does, so for every woman who is to busy thinking about everything else in life, family, work, it is one less thing to figure out, what I should eat and what workout should I do, some of us need a little no brainers and convenience in our lives, Michael
Exactly.
Banker robbers should get civil servant pay since they are all insured by taxpayers and basically can never fail. The politicians are owned by bankers who laugh at everyone
Yes, every time I hear someone say that "racism is no longer prevalent in the US", I want to tell them that they are just not paying attention.
so much for the post racial America

Americans do have a strong propensity to think that killing people is the way to solve problems. The kid was merely following the style of thoughts of his elders, he just didn't have mature judgement as to when to make such suggestions.

Unnoticed by this column was the standard piece of conservative propaganda that was subtly introduced by the show. After all, the amount of US treasury bonds held by the Chinese isn't that big a problem. It is much less serious than the continued depression, the drop in government spending as a share of the economy, and the heavy weight of PRIVATE debt that also holds down aggregate demand. But the debt to China is a favorite talking point of conservatives who are trying to reduce social spending.

I don't suppose the correct answer was explained to the kids -- ignore the debt until the depression ends, and then raise taxes.

There was a time when many people stood on the sideline as Africans were traded as slaves, Jews rounded up and sent to concentration camps, suspected "commies" dragged in front of McCarthy's hearings, etc. The bystanders were complicit in endorsing cruelty and ill-will upon another human being.

Of the three networks, ABC News is a standout on using American Flag waving and "Made in America" as their calling card. It borders on overt xenophobic propaganda. Let's see how long the White House can remain silent on ABC & Kimmel's "kill everyone in China" to solve American's debt and unemployment problems.

Check out this: http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/11/06/21329591-distasteful-and-o...
Now tell us the difference.
Inciting genocide is inexcusable. Kimmel, the Kill'emAll needs to go!
Stand up firmly and speak out loudly to those who have a habit and culture to step on weak ones. For not doing so, we are inviting more abuses and possible genocide in future. Remember: “Weakness is provocative” - Donald Rumsfeld
It's the down side of free speech....The Chinese will just have to live with it....they wish.....
How on earth does this end up in my recommended list by the NYT?
